Dispute_Type: Charter rights and extraterritorial application of Canadian law
Legal_Issue: Whether detainee transfers by Canadian Forces in Afghanistan violate the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Decision_Outcome: Applicants granted public interest standing; motion to strike dismissed
Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to demonstrate serious legal issues, genuine interest, and no alternative remedy
Legal_Rule: The Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms applies domestically with limited extraterritorial reach; public interest standing requires: (1) serious justiciable issue, (2) genuine interest, and (3) no other reasonable and effective manner to bring the issue before the court
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness depending on the nature of the legal question
Procedural_Issue: Motion to strike the judicial review application for lack of standing
Grounds_for_Claim: Detainee transfer practices may result in torture, violating Charter rights
Decision_Maker: Judge hearing the judicial review application
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Applicants meet public interest standing requirements
Key_Evidence_Considered: Allegations of risk of torture following detainee transfers
Legal_Framework: Canadian administrative and constitutional law, Charter jurisprudence
Applicant_Challenge: Challenging the legality of detainee transfers under the Charter
Court_Result: Standing granted; case not struck out
Legal_Rule_Source: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, case law on public interest standing (e.g., Borowski, Downtown Eastside Sex Workers)
Standard_of_Proof: Low threshold for public interest standing â€“ serious issue, not necessarily a winning argument
Defendant_Response: Charter does not apply extraterritorially; no identifiable individual victims; no standing
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, affidavits, policy documents related to detainee transfers
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of detainee transfer practices
Remedy_Sought: Declaration that detainee transfers violate the Charter
Legal_Provision: Section 7 and Section 12 of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Legal_Provision_Cited: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, sections 7, 12
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Extraterritoriality, lack of standing, absence of specific harm
Governing_Rule: Public interest standing doctrine and Charter applicability abroad
